flow.context: Steve Schwab is CEO of Casago, which closed its acquisition of Vacasa on May 1, 2025 — now managing 40,000+ vacation rental properties across North America through a franchise-first model. He's navigating the biggest integration in vacation rental history: merging Vacasa's centralized tech stack (HomeCare Hub, post-clean photo approval workflows) with Casago's locally empowered franchise operators. Casago just partnered with Breezeway for ops and Guesty for PMS across the network, and expanded its San Diego franchise with 150+ former Vacasa homes in August 2025. Sam's SoCal roots, surfing background, and RapidEye's Breezeway integration create a natural entry point.

gatekeeper_initial.label: GATEKEEPER — SLIDE BY
gatekeeper_initial.say: Hey, could you get me through to Steve? It's Sam.
gatekeeper_initial.note: Don't volunteer anything else. Pause and wait. Sound like you belong.

branches.label: Who's calling / what's this about?
Putting you through
He's not available / in a meeting

gatekeeper_context.label: GATEKEEPER — ADD CONTEXT
gatekeeper_context.say: Yeah, I work with a few property management companies out in San Diego — we actually work with some folks using Breezeway. Would you mind letting Steve know it's Sam Parks?
gatekeeper_context.note: Name-drop Breezeway casually since Casago just partnered with them. Don't pitch. Don't explain what RapidEye does.

branches.label: What company are you with / what's this regarding?
Putting you through
He's not available

gatekeeper_social_proof.label: GATEKEEPER — SOCIAL PROOF
gatekeeper_social_proof.say: We help a couple property management companies with their inspection workflows — I actually sent Steve a note already. Would you mind giving him a heads up that Sam Parks is on the line?
gatekeeper_social_proof.note: Imply prior contact. Stay calm, don't oversell. If they push back again, accept it and get contact info.

branches.label: Putting you through
Can't connect you / take a message

gatekeeper_blocked.label: GATEKEEPER — BLOCKED
gatekeeper_blocked.say: Totally understand. Would you mind sharing his direct line or best email so I can follow up directly? I want to make sure it's actually relevant before I bother him again.
gatekeeper_blocked.note: Get whatever info you can. Likely email patterns: steve.schwab@vacasa.com or steve-schwab@vacasa.com. If they give nothing, try calling back at a different time.

opener.label: OPENER — CONTEXT + NAME + HOOK
opener.say: Hey Steve — I work with a few property managers in the San Diego market, I'm actually from LA originally, spent half my weekends surfing down there. It's Sam Parks with RapidEye. Have you heard my name tossed around?
opener.note: Feet up on the desk energy. Smile. Don't rush. The surf mention is genuine — Steve's based in SD, Sam's from LA, it's a natural SoCal bond. Pause after the question.

branches.label: Yeah I think so / sounds familiar
No, I haven't / who?
I'm busy / bad time
What is this about / what are you selling?

heard_yes.label: THEY'VE HEARD OF YOU
heard_yes.say: Oh nice — well normally we'd be working with someone in your position. What'd you hear?
heard_yes.note: Let him talk. Whatever he says, bridge into discovery questions. Don't correct anything — just listen and pivot.

branches.label: Describes what he heard / asks a question
Vague / not sure actually

heard_no.label: HAVEN'T HEARD — TRANSITION TO PAIN
heard_no.say: Ha — guess I'm not as popular as I thought. Well the reason for my call is —
heard_no.note: Keep it light. Pause briefly after this line and move straight into the pain trigger. This is just a bridge sentence.

branches.label: Continues listening

bad_timing.label: BAD TIMING — RESCHEDULE
bad_timing.say: Totally hear you — would it be a terrible idea if I tried you again later this week? Maybe Thursday afternoon?
bad_timing.note: Suggest a specific day and time. Sound casual, not desperate. If he gives a hard no, don't push.

branches.label: Sure, try me then / gives a time
Not interested / don't call back

bad_timing_rebook.label: CALLBACK LOCKED
bad_timing_rebook.say: Perfect — I'll try you Thursday around two your time. Appreciate it, Steve.
bad_timing_rebook.note: Lock the callback. Write it down immediately. Don't re-pitch. Just confirm and hang up cleanly.

permission_fallback.label: PERMISSION ASK — 30 SECONDS
permission_fallback.say: Yeah totally — I mean it is a cold call. Can I get thirty seconds to tell you why I reached out, and you can totally hang up on me if it's not a fit?
permission_fallback.note: This resets the dynamic. Most people will give 30 seconds out of curiosity or politeness. If he says yes, go straight to pain trigger.

branches.label: OK go ahead / sure
No thanks / not interested

permission_rejected.label: PERMISSION DENIED — SPLIT THE OBJECTION
permission_rejected.say: Shoot, totally my bad. Just so nobody from my team bugs you again — is it that I caught you at a horrible time, or is it that you already know what we do and it's just not interesting?
permission_rejected.note: You need to understand if it's timing or a real rejection. The split forces a more honest answer than a blanket no.

branches.label: Bad timing / caught me at a bad moment
Not interested / not relevant
Hangs up / hard no

split_bad_timing.label: IT'S TIMING — GET A CALLBACK
split_bad_timing.say: Got it — when would be less terrible? I can try you back whenever works best.
split_bad_timing.note: Get a specific day and time. Write it down. If he's vague, suggest Thursday or next week.

branches.label: Gives a day or time
Vague / just email me

split_not_relevant.label: NOT RELEVANT — PIVOT TO REFERRAL
split_not_relevant.say: Totally fair. Out of curiosity — who on your team would be closest to the inspection and turnover piece across the franchise network? I don't wanna waste your time if there's someone better to talk to.
split_not_relevant.note: Steve is CEO-level and may delegate. Ideal referrals: John Banczak (COO), Bob Milne (SVP Ops), or Alex Johnson (VP Franchise Ops).

branches.label: Gives a name or title
No one / won't say

pain_trigger.label: PAIN TRIGGER — PEER STORY
pain_trigger.say: I was talking to another CEO running a franchise-model vacation rental network — not quite your scale, but similar setup — and he kept running into this gap. His local teams were taking inspection photos after every turnover, hundreds a day across markets, and technically someone was supposed to review them before the next guest arrived. But at that volume, stuff was slipping through — a stained sofa cushion, a cracked tile, a missing remote — and it'd show up in a guest review before anyone on his team even knew about it. Then the homeowner calls asking why they're paying management fees when nobody caught it. He said the worst part was they actually had the photos. Someone just didn't have time to look at them all.
pain_trigger.note: PAUSE after this. Do NOT jump to the solution. Let Steve react. This pain maps directly to his world: franchise operators, photo volume at 40K+ homes, owner churn, guest review damage. The silence is where the magic happens.

branches.label: Yeah that's exactly our problem / resonates
Hmm interesting / tell me more
We've got that covered / we have a process
That's not really our issue

pain_positive.label: PAIN LANDED — DEEPEN IT
pain_positive.say: Yeah — and I'd imagine with forty thousand-plus homes across the franchise network, that problem just multiplies, right? Especially with the Vacasa integration still settling in and local teams running things their own way in each market?
pain_positive.note: He's engaged. Acknowledge the scale and reference the acquisition naturally. Don't overdo the research flex — just show you understand his world. Then move to solution.

branches.label: Agrees / shares more detail
It's complicated / we're working on it

pain_skeptical.label: PAIN LUKEWARM — REDIRECT TO THEIR WORKFLOW
pain_skeptical.say: Yeah, and honestly a lot of the property managers I talk to feel the same way at first. The thing is, the photos are already being taken — your teams are already doing post-clean submissions through the field app. The question is really just whether anyone's actually catching everything in those photos at this kind of scale, or if some stuff's getting through.
pain_skeptical.note: Don't argue. Acknowledge the lukewarm response and redirect to their existing workflow. Mentioning the field app and post-clean photo submissions shows you know how they operate.

branches.label: That's fair / we do miss stuff sometimes
We catch most of it / it's fine

solution_and_cta.label: ONE-LINE SOLUTION + CTA
solution_and_cta.say: So what we built — we're an AI layer that plugs into the inspection photos your teams are already taking. It connects right into Breezeway, which I know you guys just rolled out across the network, and it automatically flags damage, missing items, staging issues — before the next guest checks in. No workflow change for your local teams at all. Would you be open to taking a look when I'm not cold calling you out of the blue?
solution_and_cta.note: One sentence on what it does. Name-drop Breezeway — Casago literally just partnered with them. Emphasize no workflow change. Keep the CTA light and self-deprecating.

branches.label: Yeah I'd take a look / sounds interesting
Send me an email / some info
We don't have budget for that
I'm not sure we need that

warm_discovery.label: THEY'RE WARM — STOP PITCHING, ASK QUESTIONS
warm_discovery.say: Awesome. So — now that you've brought Vacasa under the Casago umbrella, how are you thinking about standardizing the inspection piece across all the franchise operators? Is that something that's top of mind right now or more of a down-the-road priority?
warm_discovery.note: STOP PITCHING. You're in discovery mode. Steve is CEO-level so keep questions strategic — don't get into weeds about checklists or photo counts. Listen for: who owns this, what's broken, what's the timeline, what would make him act.

branches.label: Shares details about inspection strategy / challenges
We're ready to see a demo / let's set up a time
I'm not the right person for this / talk to my ops team

deeper_discovery.label: DIG INTO THE GAP
deeper_discovery.say: That makes sense. And right now when a local franchise team submits their post-clean photos — is someone actually reviewing those in real time before the next guest arrives, or is it more of a spot-check thing that varies by market?
deeper_discovery.note: Dig into the gap between what's supposed to happen and what actually happens. At 40K+ homes the answer is almost certainly inconsistent. Listen for specific pain — missed damage, owner complaints, review fallout, staff bandwidth. If he starts talking about who owns this internally, let him go and take notes.

branches.label: Answers honestly / shares the gap
You should really talk to my ops people about this
Send me something and I'll loop in the team

objection_no_budget.label: OBJECTION — NO BUDGET
objection_no_budget.say: Totally get it — especially with everything going into the Vacasa integration right now, I'm sure budgets are locked down tight. Just so nobody from my team cold calls you again — is it that budget for this cycle is completely spoken for, or is it more that anything new has to go through a gauntlet to get approved?
objection_no_budget.note: Acknowledge the acquisition cost context specifically — it shows empathy and research. Split the objection. Both answers lead to the test drive pitch.

branches.label: Budget is completely locked / spoken for
Approval process is brutal / has to go through layers
Hard no / just not interested

objection_not_interested.label: OBJECTION — NOT INTERESTED
objection_not_interested.say: I totally get it — I probably should've assumed you'd be all set on this. With forty thousand homes and a franchise network you'd have to have something in place. Just so I don't have my team bug you again — is it that inspections aren't really a priority right now, or is it more that you just hate cold calls?
objection_not_interested.note: Disarm with self-deprecation and humor. The split forces an honest answer. If it's 'hate cold calls,' that's actually an opening — it means the topic might be fine, just not the channel.

branches.label: Inspections aren't a priority right now
I just hate cold calls / bad channel
Hard no / don't call again

objection_have_process.label: OBJECTION — ALREADY HAVE A PROCESS
objection_have_process.say: That makes total sense — I know you guys have HomeCare Hub with the photo submissions built in, plus the Breezeway rollout happening across the franchise network. Honest question though — is it that you're fully covered and catching everything at scale, or is it more that layering anything else in during the integration would just be too much right now?
objection_have_process.note: Show you know their stack — HomeCare Hub and Breezeway. Crucially: RapidEye isn't replacing Breezeway, it's an AI layer ON TOP of it. The split distinguishes between 'we're happy' and 'we're overwhelmed,' which are very different objections.

branches.label: We're happy with what we have / it works
It's more about timing / too much change right now
Actually it's not perfect / we do miss stuff

sell_test_drive.label: SELL THE TEST DRIVE
sell_test_drive.say: Look, you're probably not buying anything right now with the integration still going on, and I totally respect that. But when things do settle and you're looking at how to scale quality consistently across the franchise network — the people who move fastest are the ones who already know what's on their list. Would you be open to just seeing what it looks like? Even if it's just to see what other PM companies running forty thousand-plus homes are doing with their turnover photos. Worst case you steal some ideas and we part as friends.
sell_test_drive.note: Low pressure. Frame it as future planning, not a purchase decision. The 'steal ideas' line gives him a reason to say yes without committing to anything. Match his scale — 40K+ homes — so he knows you're not pitching a small-operator tool.

branches.label: OK sure, let's set something up
Send me something first
Talk to my ops team instead
Not right now / no thanks

referral_pivot.label: REFERRAL — GET THE RIGHT PERSON
referral_pivot.say: Totally makes sense — you've got bigger fish to fry at the CEO level. Who on your team would be closest to the inspection workflow and the Breezeway rollout across the franchise network? Would that be someone like John Banczak or Bob Milne, or is there somebody else who owns that piece?
referral_pivot.note: Name-drop the COO and SVP Ops by name. This shows serious research and makes it easy for Steve to confirm or redirect. Alex Johnson (VP Franchise Ops) is another strong target if he mentions franchise standardization.

branches.label: Gives a name or confirms John/Bob/Alex
I'll pass your info along internally
Won't give a name / figure it out

referral_get_name.label: REFERRAL — LOCK THE WARM INTRO
referral_get_name.say: Perfect — really appreciate that. Would you be open to shooting them a quick note so it doesn't land like another cold pitch? Or if it's easier, I'll just mention you pointed me their way when I reach out.
referral_get_name.note: The warmest intro wins. 'Steve pointed me your way' is gold even if Steve doesn't send an email himself. Get the person's direct line or email if possible. Confirm spelling of the name.

branches.label: Sure I'll send a note / mention my name
Just email them directly / here's their info
Vague / noncommittal

book_meeting.label: BOOK THE MEETING — LOCK IT NOW
book_meeting.say: Let me pull up my calendar — I've got next Tuesday and Thursday open. How does Tuesday afternoon look, maybe two o'clock Pacific? I'll shoot over the invite right now so it's locked in. Really appreciate you taking my call, Steve.
book_meeting.note: Pick a specific day and time — don't say 'when works for you.' Send the invite while on the phone. Once booked, STOP SELLING. Confirm the email for the invite — likely steve.schwab@vacasa.com. If booking with a referral, adjust the name and get their email.

send_email.label: SEND ME AN EMAIL — ACCEPT AND EXTRACT
send_email.say: Totally fair. One quick question before I do — what would be most useful to include so it doesn't feel like another generic vendor pitch? I want to make sure it's actually worth opening.
send_email.note: Get intel on what matters to him — is it ROI numbers, case studies at scale, integration details with Breezeway, or something else? Include a specific meeting time suggestion in the email. Use steve.schwab@vacasa.com. If this was a referral, ask for the referral's email and mention Steve's name in the subject line.

end_graceful.label: END GRACEFULLY
end_graceful.say: Totally understand, Steve. If anything changes down the road — especially as the franchise network scales and you're looking at how to keep inspections consistent — I'm easy to find. Appreciate your time.
end_graceful.note: Don't burn the bridge. Steve is CEO of a 40K+ property empire — even if today's a no, he may mention RapidEye to his ops team later. Leave a good impression. Stay warm, not bitter.
